pageContext.claim: “Net farm income, because our economy is doing so well, is forecast to be nearly $8 billion higher than in 2016.”
pageContext.analysis: Trump is cherry-picking a factoid here. Net farm income in 2019 is expected to be about $6 billion higher than 2018, according to the U.S. Department of Agriculture, and about $6 billion less than 2017. So Trump reached back to 2016 to come up with an $8 billion increase. After adjusting for inflation, net farm income in 2019 will still be among the lowest 25 percent since 1929, according to the American Farm Bureau Federation.
